> > As far as I have gathered, it isn't.  But because he is climbing
> > the CURRENT hill, he may avoid some of those pitfalls.
>
>I think I'm still not getting something.  What's good about the
>current hill?  I thought the whole problem usually is to find the
>right hill with no prior information.

Depends.

>Is he assuming we already start with a solution?

For the robot, no.  For the creativity machine, yes.

>And if so, then what's the point?

For the creativity machine?  To find valid but untried combinations.  To be 
creative.

>Just to
>track a slowly moving landscape?  There are probably better ways to
>do even that; for example, particle swarm optimization.

Can you summarize what particle swarm optimization is in a few sentences?

>I guess I'm missing the big picture.  His method wouldn't e.g.
>discover a biped walking network right?

Don't know.  It might.  Depends on the hurdles it has to overcome to do so.  
And it does depend on having an appropriate topology already in place.  But 
in theory, he can perform a single evaluation on a network, during which 
time the weights automatically optimize, and know at the end if the topology 
is adequate.  As opposed to going through hundreds of evaluations during 
which you try thousands of weight combinations looking for that magical 
minimized error point.

It assumes that if you just always climb up hill a little at a time while 
the hills are moving, you will eventually end up at the highest peak.  Is it 
true?  Will it work?  For a controller, maybe.  If you have enough 
evaluations and changes per second, it might actually be true.  Only 
experimentation will say for sure if it holds true for a given problem 
domain.

But that holds true for back-propagation, too.  In most cases, they don't 
analyze all the training samples before adjusting weights.  They would like 
to, but it is too computationally intensive.  Instead, they do minor 
adjustments after each evaluation, and have the same exact hope that given 
enough time, they will find the highest peak.  You would expect that his 
approach, though dependant on randomness instead of calculus, should 
experience about the same kind of results.  And back-propagation tends to 
have a pretty good track record, from what I've read.

>It sounds like it just
>takes some preconstructed solution and gets "creative" on it by
>randomly messing it up and hoping something interesting pops out.
>Is that the big idea?

For the creativity machine, yes.  Which, if your goal is creativity, that's 
a good thing!  For instance, he has made a network that composes music.  
Personally, I'd like to recreate that particular experiment...

>I don't know, I'm still skeptical about his sanity.  I would expect
>technology investors to be paranoid about people who claim to have
>the ultimate solution to AI.

I would, too.  And his claim *IS* over-hyped.  It doesn't yet yeild a 
thinking machine.  Is he on track to making one?  That is too early to tell. 
  But some of the technologies he has produced ARE impressive and useful.  
The security scanning tool, for instance.

>Actually, interestingly, there was a guy I met an AI & Games
>conference who contacted me earlier in the year asking for my
>professional assessment of Thaler's work.  I didn't know anything
>about Thaler at the time, but I looked at his website and told the
>guy I couldn't evaluate it well because there isn't any technical
>information but that the claims sound unrealistic.

Yes, some of the claims are a little premature.  Other claims are fantastic, 
but real.  Unless he lied, he really did build a network that invents words, 
and another that invents music, and another that invented the Oral-B 
cross-action toothbrush.  And I don't even know what else, but I recall 
there being other things, too.

>All government funding agencies have grant reviews done by academic
>peers.  Are there really investors out there who put millions of
>dollars down without consulting an expert just because someone
>claims to have discovered the key to intelligence?

There's probably a few.  But who makes an investment decision based on the 
web site alone?  The website is the lure.  Then they contact him for more 
info.  And then sign an NDA in order to get that info...  And if they like 
what they see, then they invest.  Or if he's a really good con-man...

I'm not worried about it.  I'm not investing in him.  But I see potential in 
his work, which is why I brought it up.  So we can learn from it. :)

-- John
